Sadly, it's also usually foggy and cold here ... couple that with being wet after paddling and it's not a pretty combo.

The water itself is gross, and there is Old Salty, this crazy old man who hangs out at the docks yelling at you for looking at his sinking boat the wrong way.  It's also a breeding ground for mosquitoes ... so stay away from the water after sunset. 

Lots of dragonboat teams still practice out on this water.  I'm really sorry.
author: Kathleen W.

description: Running Lake Merced always a good workout. The number and diversity of runners definitely keeps me motivated to finish the 4.4 miles around! I just wish it was just a bit warmer in this part of the city.
author: Kaithlyn R.

description:
Great part of the city that not many people get to see...with Golden Gate Park getting all the top-billing. Thats ok, because GGP takes all of the tour buses and the hippies. 
Lake Merced is 4 miles around, with a great trail to run, bike, "blade", or leer at people from afar, which legally I can't do anymore. But don't worry about me. 
The lake was in danger of disappearing because of damage from the '89 earthquake. But the City and different volunteer organizations have put in alot of hard work to reverse that and  make this a great place to go. Probably for the President's Cup last fall at Harding, and the U.S. Open next year at the Olympic Club. Anywho  My mom runs it all the time and hasn't had a problem with safety.....or hippies. So go out on a Saturday morning sometime and get some exercise
author: Kevin M.

description:
This is a really good place to run, power walk or bike! You get the workout you need without paying a monthly gym membership fee. The only way to burn that fat off is doing cardio workout, and running, walking, jogging or biking this will help you achieve that! 

It's 4.5 miles around the entire lake, that is if you don't take the short cut, which is a bridge towards the Daly City part of the lake. No matter which day you come here, there are always other people around, running, walking or biking, the young and the old! It really doesn't take too long to get around the entire lake! A friend and I power walked the entire 4.5 miles in 1 hour! =) (not bad for a pair of fattys..JK)

Parking is easy to find on the weekdays, but it's a different story on the weekends! Try coming here on a nice day, so you can enjoy the view of the lake while your doing whatever your doing!
author: Heather C.

description:
The best part about living in Forest Hill and going to SFSU was the proximity to Lake Merced. Yes-that's right. Though often thought of as the red-haired stepchild of Golden Gate Park, I love Lake Merced. I can overlook the traffic because it is a perfectly-sized natural area that offers a little of everything for the discerning recreation enthusiast. There are boat rentals, fishing, dog areas, BBQ corners, and the ubiquitous golf courses-more about that later. The premier highlight for me is a continuous paved path which runs uninterrupted around both lakes. This 4.4 mile circuit is the best by far area for exercising on equipment like skates and bikes. There are easy grades, a smooth surface and not a single curbed interruption which is phenomenal! My wonderful boyfriend would always accompany me while I walked, ran, biked, and skated those paths-almost daily! It is fairly safe there and I never once had a problem.

Often times shrouded in the fog usually found in the Daly City/Pacifica area, it is a refreshing spot to just hang out in. Looking at the Lake and water is very calming for me, and I don't mind the fact that it's a senior hang out due to the nearby Doelger Senior Center.

The problem with Lake Merced is since the 1980s-there has been the three massive golf courses which surround it sucking it dry by diverting the ground water for their own irrigation needs. Harding Municipal Golf Course, Olympic Country Club, and San Francisco Golf Club surround and penetrate the lake lands like a glove around its throat-choking the life out of Lake Merced.  As a result, the lake began 'dying' as water levels dropped and water quality fell. The low point was in 1994 as the lake reached an all time low of 14 feet in depth (the top off depth is 30 feet).

The future is hopeful for Lake Merced. The same group that brought back  Mono Lake in Los Angeles is now involved with Lake Merced. The Mono Lake case set a new legal precedent for protecting the public trust and progress has been made at Lake Merced thanks to Cal Trout's clout.  Draining of the water table has been reduced by 75% and storm water will now be partially diverted into the lakes. As of April 2004, water levels are back up to around 26 feet . I last visited Lake Merced the previous summer and the situation has improved dramatically.  As for me, there is no love lost for the game of golf and the demands it's "greens" place on the environment. I wish those goofy-dressed golfers would go somewhere else to whack their balls around!
author: Gail P.

description:
I like to come here for my "Nika time"..

I have...
ridden my bicycle
gone jogging
walked each of my dogs
rode my motorcycle (not on the path, of course)

I love lake merced!

Everyone has already given the distance of this place, so I wont get into that. On sunny days it gets busier. I always sneak glances at the lake ( I don't want to trip and fall down into it..)
author: Neek W.

description: If they would implement some traffic calming and put up a nice separated bike lane around the perimeter, this would be an ultra fabulous spot for daily exercise.  It's sort of perfect because it's 4.5Mi around the path.  However, with cars regularly whizzing by you at 55-65 MPH, you sort of get that vulnerable feeling, and you can barely hear the person talking next to you.  Too bad.  The lake is awesome, and this could be a wonderful respite area with a little better planning.
author: Julie T.

description:
Good place to run or bike around.  I forget the details but I think my uncle who is a paramedic saved someone's life there.

Anyways, if you are parking there I have to warn you that near SFSU and the golf course are a lot of vehicle break-ins.  You will know because you will see glass all over the place.  Cops should patrol here more often.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Been running the lake on and off for the last few years. Gotta switch it up every so often, otherwise you'll get bored.

Overall, Lake Merced is a cool running spot. It's about a 4+ mile run. Shorter if you take the cut, but for what???! With the lake, you know what to expect. It's pretty safe out during the day and plenty of parking around. There are others around you either running or biking, so you're not alone. It's just one big circle. No surprises. The view of the lake though is breathtaking & peaceful. Nice reminder of how beautiful SF is, and how 
lucky we are to live in it.

Be careful for the birds though. They travel in packs and swoon left to right repeatedly. Haha, be sure you're not underneath them.
author: Joy A.

description:
On good days, the dragon boat paddling makes me feel great! On other days, the shotgun range makes me feel alive. On the crappy stressed out days, I like to run/jog/walk around the lake to get my eustress and LDL levels back up. On a sunny day, its a pretty decent heart pumping run. 

I think the one thing you can never get rid of from Lake Merced is that stagnant water stench that emanates from around certain areas of the lake. It's putrid and smells like old sneakers. 

If you want an exercise program, get out there and go hike around the lake! Its a free membership, just find some good parking =]
author: Jason C. J.

description: Parking is free and easy on a weekday. Me and my two friends ran this and there was enough room to run side by side. My friend says its about 4 miles :) pretty lake, and cold weather = a good run. Hopefully you don't get sand in your face like we did. If I had a dog I'd totally walk it here ;)
author: Diane S.

description:
Gun shots do not make for a pleasant, refreshing start to the day.

While training for the Kaiser Half Marathon, I came here with a friend to run two laps around Lake Merced after seeing the rave reviews here on Yelp! the week before the race.  Maybe it's because I come from the land of 10,000 lakes, or maybe it's because my training as a landscape architect has made me overly critical about park design, but I was not impressed.

The Negative: the main trail runs right along major roadways with no landform or vegetative buffer, so unless you have your iPod blaring, all you hear is traffic ... until you pass by the shooting range, and you hear the firing of rifles.  Not the calm, idyllic atmosphere I was hoping to find.  And views to the lake from the main trail that loops around are not that great.  Boring.

The Positive: you don't have to cross traffic or worry about stopping for cars as you're running around, except for the occasional driveway entrance to a parking lot, and it's nice that it's a loop ... but I'd rather run through Golden Gate Park, the Presidio, Chrissy Field or along Ocean Beach.

Maybe there are nice spots to hang out and have a picnic off of the main trail.  Perhaps I'll come back for something like that, but not to run.
author: Jamie T.

description: This is one of my favorite jogging routes in the city, a nice 4.5 mile jog around this lake is a great way to start your day. The jog is mostly flat, with tiny hills, and one medium hill, depending on where you start your run, you can either climb that hill or go down that hill. Personally i like to climb up that medium hill just to get the satisfaction of burning every possible calorie possible at lake merced. Love running this lake, get view, excellent location. Include this park as part of your training routes ! you wont regret it !
author: Jeff C.

description: I Come here every week for my runs/ walks. This is my go to spot for running. It's nice and quiet and also relaxing when you want to go on a morning walk. There's a decent amount of people here but it's not too crowded! I would recommend this place, great for families.
author: Sally L.

description:
Ingredients for a perfect running route: 

(1) plenty of parking, because the last thing you want to do is circle around to find a spot to park your car before you embark on your run; 

(2) plenty of trees, because when your old lungs are dying for air you WOULD appreciate that extra oxygen produced by the little green leaves during the photosynthesis process; 

(3) picturesque route with adequate opportunities of hill training that is NOT tourist-laden because you would rather conserve your energy to get that 8:30 pace than to have to dodge around them; 

(4) a route that is short enough to tackle in half an hour, yet has the option to be tagged on to a longer run if you feel so compelled to do it for whatever reason (e.g., you just downed the digesting yet effective 5-hr energy drink, your salt tablet is working and your legs are feeling fresh, or you just turn into beast mode after a 4.5 mile run). 

Lake Merced: check, check, check, and check. 

Re #4, Lake Merced is a perfect 4.5-mile loop, but should you feel that it's not challenging enough, you can do this (route tried and tested):
a) Start at the parking lot at the north end of the Lake http://maps.google.com/maps?saddr=Lake+Merced+Blvd&hl=en&ll=37.72952,-122.493589&spn=0.007331,0.020878&sll=37.730369,-122.492516&sspn=0.007331,0.020878&geocode=FfG0PwIdZuWy-A&vpsrc=6&mra=prev&t=m&z=16

b) run counterclockwise and 4.5 mile later, when you are back where you started, hop on Sunset Blvd and run north toward Lincoln Way - it's a nice steady uphill climb that would make you work the gluteus maximus.

c) go left on Lincoln and enjoy the refreshing downhill run toward Great Hwy - consider it a reward!

d) find the little running path on Great Highway and run south toward Lake Merced.  

e) turn left on Sloat and right on Sunset Blvd.  

f) time to pig out at Outerlands.
author: Ange L.

description: Perfect place to run. I'm training for the Giants half marathon and have been looking for scenic places to run. Lots of people running around. There was even a nice older guy encouraging as I was huffing and puffing along. The lake is about 4.5 miles around so I ran it twice. Definitely got my spirits up about running the half marathon. There's maybe about two slight areas of incline but other than that it's flat. Definitely recommend for a jog or a nice walk.
author: Rochelle I.

description:
so for college, a long looooong time ago,  i went to SFSU and always passed by Lake Merced but never gave it the time of day like i should have. today was the first time i ran around the lake. and today... i fell in love with Lake Merced. i ran this darn lake straight through, no problems (great training run if you're into marathons).

its paved the whole way, and its wide enough for maybe 4 people to run side-by-side. a lot of people seem to run/bike/walk here too so that made me feel a bit safe. there's also no inclines so you don't have to worry about huffing and puffing your way around. the scenery is kinda cool: the lake of course, the birds, and even the speeding cars passing by. best to run with the traffic instead of against it so that you wont get distracted by the speeding cars and lights

there's a few blind spots when you're rounding a curve so keep your eyes open because some bikers bike fast and you won't see them till they almost side-swipe you. 

all in all, i had a good run.
author: Summer R.

description: Lake Merced is Lake Merced--it's pretty cool. Just keep in mind if you're parking in Harding Park that there really aren't any cool paths around there; it's mostly about picnic-ing by the water or walking through the golf course. If you want to walk around Lake Merced pick another place to park.
author: Paul C.

description: Popular place for walking. If you walk a full lap using Lake Merced Blvd, John Muir Drive, and Skyline Blvd, it's an estimated 4.5 miles (from what I read before), but you'll be dealing with much traffic noise along Lake Merced Blvd. I normally just do the shorter lap: park at the Sunset Circle lot, walk across a bridge below to and then pass the golf course and picnic areas, then along a portion of Skyline and Lake Merced Blvd back to the car. This option is probably around two miles.
author: H K.

description:
I LOVE the lake.  It's definitely a stress reliever when I'm having a bad day.  I just put on my running shoes and free my mind in that 4 point something mile route.  

When the sun is out bright and shining, the bridge view is breath taking.  

only thing I do have to warn you about...

There's a guy that drives a run down blueish greenish turquoise ford (drives a white SUV now) that I have noticed who comes to the lake quite often and parks his car and sits in it to people watch.  Now, I haven't seen him do anything wrong, but I find it quite irritating that he parks his car next to mine, across from mine, or close to mine when the whole lot is open.  He sits in his car and stares.  

One time I spotted him parked in the lot off sunset blvd as I was pulling in and he moved his car a few spaces away from me after I parked.  Obviously, I'm not gonna stay. I ended up leaving and running by the beach.

Females, BEWARE.
author: Beck S.

description:
A great place to run, bike, skate, or walk around. It's 4.5 miles around, the scenery is relaxing, and not a lot of people that get in your way let's say like Golden Gate Park. Don't get me wrong, I looove GGP but that is more of a hanging out kinda park since there's so many tourists and families that go there. 

But back to Lake Merced, I really enjoy the run around this place. I'm not really a gym type of gal since I feel like I'm staring at nothing when I run on the treadmill and tend to get bored very easily. And when the weather is nice in SF, it makes for that much of a better run.
author: Krystle A.

description:
LOVE running/biking around this lake. It normally takes me about 45 minutes to run it and it's a really nice path overlooking the lake and the gorgeous homes! 

You can go deeper in and there's a park that you can bbq at and bring your dogs and have them run after the ducks in the lake. The only bad thing is you should be careful at night. They did find a few dead bodies here a couple of years ago and I did feel scared when I ran one time and it got dark too fast but I had my little pomeranian to protect me. So go here when it's sunny and enjoy it but leave before dark.
author: Lucky N.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to run long distance. This and running on the wet sand on the beach from Sloat avenue to Cliffhouse and back to Sloat. And the best thing is it's FREE! no gym membership on a lame machine where you can't do wind sprints and no monthly fees, etc.

Anyways, Lake Merced is great, it's got the pull-ups bars (working your biceps, lats, upper back, forearms, shoulders), dip bars (mainly triceps and a little chest), benches for doing leg lifts (lower abdominals), monkey bars (biceps, shoulders, etc.) spaced out around the lake. All these obstacles give you a complete body workout if you know what you are doing.

I'm probably one of the weird looking dudes that does my ab workout in the parking lot only because I'm already doing my cardio and working my legs from running. Therefore, I like to just workout my whole body.

My record for running around this lake is about 32 and a half minutes with no stops or shortcuts. Does anyone else run it faster than me? I'd like to run with you!

The only negative concern I don't like about this lake is the big parking lot where I believe people are training to be bus drivers. The bus' are polluting the air and I'm trying to run around the lake while breathing in that air, very uncool! take you're damn bus training to candlestick park!
author: Pudgy G.

description:
I used to wonder how the heck did people get down to the water to paddle and/or kayak. NOW I KNOW. Lake Merced is pretty big... about five miles or so. I used to get lost trying to find my way around but now I'm a pro. Almost.

I paddled here for my dragonboat team for half a year... Lake Merced was practically my second home. I can't believe I'm saying this, but I'm going to miss this lake once I start college. I can't give it a full 5 stars because every now and then, there's a nasty smell that lingers in the air when they clean out(?) the sewage system nearby. I can't even describe the smell... it's THAT bad. And oh, the water is pretty naaaaasty.
author: Annie S.

description:
Don't like the gym? No problem. Go to Lake Merced and have a good run. I bet you'll break a sweat in no time. 

Don't like running? No problem. Grab your friend and/or dog and walk around it. You will still break a sweat. 

Don't like walking or running? No problem! Grab your bike =)

I would suggest to bring a friend or your dog around Lake Merced though because at some parts it can get quiet. You'll usually see SFSU students or neighborhood folks running/walking/ biking around this trial when you're driving onto Sunset. 

I think the only bad thing about Lake Merced is that if you suddenly need to pee it will be hard to find a restroom.  It's an average 4-5 miles radius around the lake.
author: Tracy A.

description: Everyone knows about the lake for its long running route. There's a small shortcut through the bridge for those who want to skip out on 5-10 min. of jogging. There's always parking everywhere and the weather is always semi cooler than the rest of the city. You always see tons of bicyclists, joggers, high schoolers that are in orchestra, and pets. The only problem I probably have about this place is the smell. I don't know how often this place gets maintained but it sure seems to get pretty dirty especially around the port-o-potty near the bridge where the picnic tables are. Also, that's the area where those huge sea gulls, pigeons, and DUCKS hang out because people feed them. I cringe just thinking about it.
author: Elaine L.

description:
Lake Merced is really an ideal spot for group picnics in SF. Thanks to AJ for organizing The Proustian Potluck here, otherwise I don't know when I'd finally come to this lovely lake. Plenty of free parking, picnic tables with bbq grills, lots of grassy areas to lay out on, play frisbee and for dogs to run around. The lake and surrounding areas are beautiful and well maintained. The drive over on Skyline Blvd is scenic - there are not many things more beautiful than the sight of ocean waves crashing against the shore. 

Lake Merced is also the ideal spot for dragon boating, and after watching the racers practicing all afternoon, I was inspired to look into it (http://www.cdba.org/index.php) - even after hearing that they do an intensive conditioning workout before going out on the lake and seeing that they were high school kids. Hey, I might be twice their age and smaller than most of them, but I've got stamina and strength! 

Yeah, alright, who am I kidding? But I can always have a goal to aspire to. Only 6 more months until the next dragon boat race!
author: Connie C.

description:
Surely no other landmark in San Francisco is so conspicuous on a map of the city yet so conspicuously absent from the minds of the residents.  Notwithstanding the fact that a lot of city-dwellers probably think of this as Daly City out here.  Now with many of these overlooked parks, I would say that the city people are missing out.  But I can't blame them for not bothering with Lake Merced.

Yes, you can jog *around* Lake Merced, but with a few modest exceptions you can't penetrate the interior of the park, in particular the area between the two lakes occupied by Harding Park Golf Course.  Now I have nothing in particular against golf courses, but in a city like San Francisco it seems like an awfully big space set aside for the use of an awfully small number of people.  Thus I have three modest proposals sorted by increasing ambition:

1) Have a public right-of-way through Harding Park so people can run along the paths and enjoy the beautiful trees and grass (it *is* a public golf course, so I'm unclear on the kosherness of just running across it--there's definitely some open access--but at any rate there's no access from the east side).

2) Turn Harding Park into a regular park so that Lake Merced lives up to its potential.

3) Turn Harding Park, Lake Merced *and* the Olympic Country Club over to the GGNRA, so that the whole area becomes one huge park that can take its rightful place alongside Golden Gate Park and the Presidio.

Ok, now the golfers probably hate me.  But seriously, there are *4* golf courses nearby here!  Is there really such a high demand?
author: Wes M.

description:
My go-to running spot.  I really can't figure out exactly how long it is...  some people say 4, 4.5, or 5.  Who knows maybe it's 4.75.  Whatevs.  All I know is that running on the treadmill is BOOORING.

Pros:
-you don't have to cross any streets or worry about cars
-plenty of parking
-wide path includes a dirt portion that's a little easier on the legs
-cute dogs
-if you look at the lake, it's actually kinda pretty
-rarely crowded
-good way to escape the gym and get fresh air

Cons:
-the street side isn't quite as pretty
-half the path has zero lighting, so at night it's pitch black
-this one I just discovered:  the parking lots are a stomping ground for senile bird-lovers who come here with BUCKETS of seed to feed the poor hungry pigeons and seagulls (aka evil winged-rat scavengers).  Did I not get the memo?  Are these avian assholes going extinct?  It's really awesome when they fly in circles over the entire lot and shit all over your car!
author: Jen P.

description: This is a nice jogging or dog-walking spot. There are enough people and it is close enough to the road that I feel comfortable jogging alone here. However, the closeness to the road has its downside, since is takes away from the natural feel considerably. There are some nice views of the lake at spots. You can pick from running on a dirt trail or pavement, which is great!
author: Olivia P.

description:
It's one of the best places to run in SF because the path is paved and wide and it feels pretty long (4.5 miles).  I'm pretty slow, so it takes about 50 minutes to an hour for me to jog all the way.  I've never walked all the way around but it would probably take 1.5 - 2 hours?  If you want, you can run along the dirt path rather than the asphalt one.

It also feels safe because plenty of people jog, skate, bike and walk there and the entire path is visible to passing cars.  Not as many people bring their dogs here as I would have expected.  The downside is that the view can be boring and it's pretty flat all around.  The air quality isn't as good either due to the exhaust fumes of the passing cars.  It's not easy to cross from one side to the other and it's easy to get lost on the golf course.  The view of the lake is nice but I tend to always watch the traffic.  Lake Merced lacks the character and views of other parks in SF.  

There are several parking lots - free, easy parking.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Another in the series of local memories [mainly stemming from the three months of rowing attempted, but there are others...]. While the fog can be depressing after a number of weeks, when the mist first settles over the lake, it can be quite serene and beautiful.

- Running around the lake for endurance training. I thought my legs were going to fall off.

- Getting completely drenched in the cold, smelly water. Is there not a way to row without all that splashing?

- Eugeapalooza [http://www.yelp.com/events/san-francisco-eugeapaloza-another-fine-sf-food-bank-fund-raiser-event-bbq] in August 2007. And of course, some photos from the event: http://flickr.com/photos/suki/sets/72157601230246729/

- Dragon Boat Races that now take place on Treasure Island.

- Quiet spots around the lake to park and make out [here seem to be quite a few of these spots...]

- Proustian Picnic Potluck in March 2008 [pictures: http://www.flickr.com/photos/suki/sets/72157604078350214/]

Because of its proximity to Sunset and Sloat, I drive by the lake on many occasions - on the way to the beach, on the way to the Outer Sunset or Richmond districts. I haven't actually stopped by recently, but it always crosses my mind to do so. If only my dog's legs were a little longer, I would be able to walk around the lake with her without having to carry her 1/4 of the way around.
author: Tinna H.

description:
I owe this lake my sanity.  
A run around this beauty is a delightful stress-buster after a 3-hour exam.
Thank you Lake Merced.
author: Ravena F.

description:
Awww... you're so beautiful Lake Merced! I love you!

Ok not really... you're cute and all but you're not Gods gift to the world, alright. I mean let's be honest... you're a bit stinky and not the cleanest all around...

Ohh noo I'm just joking baby! You know you look and smell good! You're not that bad at all... You helped me get back into shape the right way, I'm always determined to make it all the way around you!

You know what, whatever... you kicked my ass, I'll admit it. You look weak but i really had trouble getting around you. I thought i could own you, but you owned me once or twice before i had your number. 

Alright fine, lets agree to disagree... It's a love hate relationship we have Merced! You're cute, you're fun, you're good for kids... I'll give you that. But you're a challenge for me to run around non-stop with those slight inclines and your nearly 4 mile length around... we can't do this anymore, I CAN'T do this anymore...

Guess I'll be seein ya when i see ya...
author: Greg G.

description:
I can't say anything about the actual lake (although on my wish list is a kayak so maybe I will be able to comment soon) but running around the lake is great.

On 09/20/2009 a half marathon will take place, oriented around this lake http://www.halfmarathons.net/usa_half_marathons_california_lake_merced_half_marathon.html

I am not trying to advertise for this marathon, but merely explain the reason why I decided to run around this lake in the first place. I had been feeling sorry for myself. I have been wearing sweatpants for weeks. Chocolate bars for dinner. I think it had to do with the foggy weather descending on the sunset after a glorious week of perfect weather two weeks earlier where it was actually so warm that i went swimming at OB without a wetsuit with all those crazy euros who didn't know any better.
Foggy SF weather is hard to deal with for a native San Diego resident. 

Anyway, so I refused to get off my ass for days but this half motivated me. It's about 4 1/3 miles around, virtually flat (as in slight uphill and downhill but nothing to complain about by sf standards) and is a paved trail around uninterrupted by stoplights so what more could you ask for? I look forward to torturing myself by running around this lake three times on 9/20.
author: Ashley B.

description: I run here fairly often, great place to get our for some air, only problem is the cars are really loud sometimes. For the most part I even enjoy it here!
author: Tiff W.

description: Good place to run as there are various parking spots all around the lake. One lap around the lake is approximately 4.5 miles and there are also various places to fish and they also have a picnic area. The route is relatively flat so no hills or sand. Some downsides including inhaling all the smog from passing cars and it can get congested at times. However overall this is a good place to run and relieve stress. Other good places to run around the area include the beach and lands end.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I have to combine two reviews (Lake itself, and Yelp event on March 8, 08).  The lake is pretty beautiful, as I got to see lots of dragon boats.  However, since the location is really close to the ocean, those who forget to bring a jacket (like me) will suffer from constant cold breezes.  Seagulls and other birds will try to eat your food if you leave it there unattended for too long.  One guy even got harassed by a seagull in the form of... well, you know what I mean :D.  For that reason, I have to give this place a 3-star.

As for the Yelp event, most people were well-prepared in terms of clothes and food.  While most of foods had too much carbohydrate, its variety helped me eat a lot.  Yelpers as usual were good to hang around with.  Other than occasional fights among dogs, we were very cordial (I almost wrote "animals" instead of "we" :P).  My rice balls went out completely, which surprised me because even with mostly-Japanese picnics, I tend to have some left-overs.  That I really appreciated.

So that gives me a 5-star, and the overall experience averages out to be a 4-star.
author: Tak K.

description:
This place has a lot of memories for me. From having picnics on the warm days, caking people on their birthdays, running around the lake, falling into the lake, or showing up at the lake every tuesday, thursday, and saturday for dragon boat practice.

It's a nice place to be when its sunny, but more often than not, it'll be foggy and/or windy. I guess thats the sort of weather you'd expect in San Francisco though, so I'm used to it. It always stumps me though those times when its sunny at my house (5 minute drive away) and its super foggy at the lake. 

Lake Merced is great for picnics and for those who want a nice 4.6(?) mile jog or a leisurely walk. Just don't go into the water. It's green and sometimes has these weird smells to it.
author: Courtney Q.

description:
'It looks like it could be nice, but I'm sure there are dead bodies floating around in there'--E.C., friend and running partner

I'm usually crazy about any 5-mile strech I can run on, but Lake Merced just isn't that great.  First of all, there should be trails closer to the lake.  I mean, if you catch it on the right day, Lake Merced is a nice looking body of water!  Why on earth would anyone rather run on street level?

Secondly, there are no lights!  Don't even think about running on this thing after sundown if you're female.  It's pitch black and, unlike downtown SF, largely deserted.

Finally...this lake is kinda ugly.  The water itself is alright, but the actual running path is a bit depressing.  Again, this spot could seriously benefit from adding trails.

I'm giving it three stars because it sports a joint-saving dirt path and is very close to both SFSU and Ocean Beach.
author: Karin H.

description:
This is a great place to run/walk/bike. It's 4.5 miles with a slight incline/decline depending which way you decide to run. If 4.5 miles is too overwhelming, there is a bridge near Brotherhood way that can take you to the other side of the lake. 

There are pull up bars/rings, sit-up benches, and various other equipment along the route to help you stretch and add variation to your workout. 

It's nice that you can run this whole loop without having to stop for traffic. There is a decent amount of traffic around the lake. There is always someone around so you can feel pretty safe.
author: Allan M.

description:
i live in the outer sunset and on days when i'm just not in the mood to treadmill it - i venture out for a run to Lake Merced. 

i used to drive to the lake and make the 4.5mi run. but when i needed to increase my mileage i started running from my house to Lake Merced and back - this gave me about 6.5 miles. 

and what an ideal run this started to become: you've got the obstacles of pedestrians, bikes, dogs, and seeing if the car at the intersection is going to let you go or not - all before you reach the lake! and did i forget to mention my phobia of twisting my ankle from stepping down from the sidewalk? i know. dramatic. 

i like the terrain at lake merced in that it's not always flat but also gives you a hill if you so desire. i personally always run clockwise to avoid the hill near parkmerced apartments. :) plus, i've got steep hills on my way back home anyways. 

all in all, one of my go-to runs when i'm feeling like a chunkler.
author: Maria B.

description:
Lake Merced is my best friend and my homy. When I don't visit you that weekend, I feel like a fatty the following week. It's an addiction to see you once a week. You make me feel fit, beautiful and great when I complete you. I will never cheat you with a treadmill. I HATE treadmill. It's so boring. Unlike the treadmill, you provide me fresh air that I love =]

It certainly has help me maintain my weight for all these years. I've been jogging here once a week every Sunday (mostly) or Saturday for the past 5-6 years with my aunt and uncles. Like all the comments below it's a great place to jog/run, walk or bike. I believe it's about 4.5 or 5 miles. I complete it within 43-45 mins of non-stop. Though it's hard to accomplish in the beginning, but it's doable. 

I like how there are no traffic lights that you need to worry about. It's big enough that you can pass by walkers. I prefer to jog over walking because it took me once 1 hour 15 mins or 30 mins to complete the whole round. It helps me take my mind off work, school, and what not. Plenty of space. 

My goal is to continue jogging here until I can no longer jog. 

BEWARE: don't park your car by the lake next to SFSU at night or over night. I've seen many cars broken in.
author: MT D.

description: Been here only once, kayaking, and it was such a great experience.  Water was calm, teams out in their dragon boats racing each other, ducks paddling around the shallow end and enough green grass to lay back and have a picnic.
author: Joshua P.

description:
When you are walking/jogging/running around this lake, you almost forget that you are in San Francisco. 

4.5 miles around (if you take the bridge), or 5 miles, going all the way around. 

Usually not too crowded, unless there is some sort of relay race going on.

Need a restroom? Two porto-potties conveniently interspersed on the loop. 

Parking is available.
author: Misha F.

description:
I used to love running around here...despite the traffic/smog you get on two sides (north bound and south bound) of the run.

Somedays it would be crowded and I hate the bikers, "TO THE LEFT!"...hey, go bike in TRAFFIC!

I enjoyed the occassional hottie jogging shirtless...muscles, glistening with sweat.  (haha)

Mostly, not-too-thin people getting their "jog on"...okay, more like their "stroll-on".  Kudos to them for getting out there!

Some areas KICK ASS!  Going up hill...you feel those glutes BIG TIME!

The best part is once you go half way...you have to go all the way!  No way to seriously cheat the trail.  Okay, I know of two little cheat points, but we'll pretend that I don't know about them and we'll pretend that I've never used them either!

Maybe, I'll drive up the Peninsula to do the trail for old time's sake.  Then again, I may as well go up the street to do the Fort Funston trail...which I love, but what sucks are the dogs.  I love dogs, but I've been leg humped and butt sniffed there on more than one occasion.  

Oh yeah, did they ever get around to fixing the collapsing side walk on the Daly City side?  That sucked.

:(
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
A lovely zone in SF with great recreational offerings - some very nice driving roads around here to boot.

It cannot be coincidence that the etymology of the word 'mercy' the Medieval Latin 'merced' relates to reward - take mercy on yourself and reward your spirit with a diversion to Lake Merced, one of SF's natural oases in the city.
author: GIR ..

description:
Strangely enough, this is one of my favorite places to think about life and the shit/blessings that come with it. Nothing forces you to think about life more than an almost five mile walk around the lake with faces that don't come too often and cyclists that tell you they're coming with a "passing on the left!"

If you are a solo walker/runner, you won't be stressin' over who's there and you'll go unbothered the whole time. You might get some love from the drivers along the north side of the Lake, so shake your junk. JK There are some patches of vines that make you think you're being watched, but it's more likely to be squirrels than a serial killer.

One last point...this is a nice place to be able to say good morning to your fellow lake walkers. And you know what, they'll say hi back. That's flossy.
author: Charlene L.

description: Nice place to go running. Too bad I have tendinitis in my ankle area and have to cut down on my running. I find it best to run in the morning when there's still some fog/cloud cover because I don't enjoy the sun beating down on me while I run. Parking is somewhat easier in the morning too, at least from my experience.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
One of my favorite things to do on a quiet Sunday morning is to camp out on my couch and catch up on the news online. But more often than not, I find myself just staring out the window. I watch cars go by, birds swooping onto the lake and frighteningly enough, male joggers going pee! 

Okay, it's not like they're whipping out their johnsons right on the path and whizzing everywhere as they jog. No, they all seem to be drawn to one particular tree right across the street from my window. I've seen them slow down to an amble, walk up behind the tree, pretend to be watching the canoe team and then turn around and release the snake. Though I have to say, I can't blame them. That porta-potty by the parking lot smells ungodly. 

Anyhow, I''ve named the tree "Petri" (get it? Pee tree. Har har, I am so clever.)
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Training for a 1/2 marathon, I jogged the around this huge lake on a Saturday morning. Checked online and it's approximately 4.5 miles if you stay along the trail of the lake. It wasn't surprising to see several other joggers in groups or going solo. There were also some walkers and the occasional bike rider.

The trail is pretty wide to accomodate groups of joggers or the biker with jogger combo. It offers a the asphalt pavement as well as a narrow dirt pavement. It's pretty much flat the entire way through, minor elevation changes, but nothing to complain about.

The weather was pretty much gloomy with the beautiful white sky of SF, but I like that better than a exhausting heat that gets me dehydrated easily. Since I'm used to running in residentials, it's good to see a scenic golf course and lake. 

Overall: Good run! Will try to aim for 2 laps in the future.
author: Paul D.

description: When I'm in the city and in the mood to run, I go to Lake Merced. I usually start at the parking lot at Brotherhood and Lake Merced Blvd and run clockwise. Going this way, you'll feel slight increases in elevation and will be rewarded with a long way down near the end of the loop. Even though I don't use them, I think the exercise stations along the way are pretty nifty. Water fountains can be found along the route too. My friend who isn't a fan of asphalt also likes this run because there's a dirt path alongside the main one. Lake Merced is a nice little haven in the city since scenic landscapes can calm a soul while she is running her butt off!
author: Diana C.

description:
Absolutely a great place to run in San Francisco, and while the entire route around the lake is only ~4.5 miles, it's very easy to adjust this if you want to run more by heading to the Great Highway to jog up the coast.

I ran at 9am which is normally a lot later than I'd like to but being that it's San Francisco, it was still cold and windy. Parking was a bit of a mess and I had to park in a non-spot in the lot and hoped I wouldn't be towed (but this was with Team In Training, so we did come with a lot of cars). 

The route is clean, wide, gentle up-and-down hills, and everyone seemed friendly. Highly recommended for a way to run and relax.
author: Tracy O.

description:
I've only recently ran this place or almsot ran the entire thing, this past weekend in an attempt to get into better shape while preparing for a 1/2 marathon. This place is pretty cool, I like it. They keep the grass area in Harding area pretty neatly trimmed, there's not as much dog crap that one would expect, and there's so much stuff to do interms of keeping one active. You can run, bike ride, picnic, paddle(dragonboat/kayaking/etc), and there's many people here!

Just a hint of advice, don't come here at night. It's scary and I'm pretty sure there's some hoodlums here at times breaking into cars and stuff... so I wouldn't advice to be here past day light without anyone else. 

Anyways, I come here to dragonboat and run... and picnic at times. It's what my weekly routine revolves around. It's weird if I don't smell the funky lake water at least twice a week. I'll give it a four stars since I've been coming here nearly every other day for the past few years haha... Plus it's near a lot of other stuff.. so if I want to go play ball at Lowell or go get some food at Daly City or Sloat Blvd, it's convent 

minus one star cause the water should be sucked out to see whats underneath the lake (dead bodies, watches/oakley glasses/keys, more bodies... lochness monster) and then replaced with some fresh water that we can see the bottom of the water with :]
author: Stanley C.

description:
Do not like. I drive by here all the time and think that it maybe a nice area to run. I live on the Peninsula area, but sometimes I travel to SF to work.  Tried it out yesterday and I'm not too thrilled.  

First of all, you are not running along the lake.  You're running on a busy street inhaling exhaust.  After you make a turn, the traffic sound subsides, and you're greeting with firing rifle sounds..... not a nice scene.  I looked at the lake and kept telling myself, OMG, this cannot be only 4.5 miles, it's gonna be 12!! yeah, it felt like 12, not because it was hilly, but it was boring and ugly.  I'm too spoiled by the nice scenary in the  peninsula area.

If you don't mind the scenary, it's a good distance to run for a short run 4.5 miles.
author: Dorna C.

description:
What could be better than taking a walk around a beautiful lake.When I am not feeling lazy I enjoy a little walk.i have yet to bring out the bike to ride around the lake.

Very nice place to enjoy some fresh air.

Plenty of parking on the side near Sunset Blvd.
author: Dani D.

description: A place I grew up going to and still return here from time to time.  I have a lot of many fond memories of this place.  This is a wonderful place to have a picnic, take a nice walk|speed walk|run around the 6 mile circumference of the lake.  You can fish, boat, golf, feed ducks, birdwatching, have lunch in your car, people watch, or spend family time on a Sunday afternoon.  It is often times foggy but that is what makes this place so special.  You appreciate the beauty of this lake even in the coldest, ugliest, muggiest days.
author: Lyn D.

description: This is definitely my favorite place in the City to run. Im a little biased because I live nearby but it really is an amazing 4.5 mile run. I never have to worry about parking. There are plenty of bathrooms. I dont ever get bored because there are so many things to check out. Depending on when you go there are rowers in the water, people shooting guns at the range, little animals on the trail, golfers. It just makes the time go by faster when you feel like you cant go anymore. I have never had an issue regarding safety but then again, I never go at night.
author: Lauren N.

description:
Yup,this place is great if you don't like (or can't tolerate) steep hills and you like foliage. It's a nice, mostly even-grounded walk with slight inclines. I think you will get about 5 miles out of it if you decide to walk the whole length of it.  I like Lake Merced because on sunny days ( it's very nice on days like this), you can head on down and gander at the beautiful scenery and work your body out at the same time.  So I frequent this place when I don't go to the gym (What's the gym?). Lake Merced is better than the gym...but anyway...

If you have the time to take your time, try going down one of the many paths you'll find as you walk the span of the lake. Your breath will be taken away by what you see-- good or.....(Caution!!!!! : you may walk into someone's makeshift living quarters).  Just be cautious, hehe, when I was a wee one, my dad took me out to one of the docks out there and we happened upon someone's living space.... including toilet space... my dad was like, "it's time to go home". I'll leave it at that.
author: Janielle L.

description: For all those nature lovers out there, this is a great place to go for a run. Even though I live next to a school with fields, I prefer this because it has great view, there's dirt/tar pavements (I'm not a fan of cement- sorry!), very minor wind, and has mostly flat land with the exception of minor "hills" if you run the entire lake. Not really sure how long it is around the lake but it's about 4.5ish miles around the entire place. Love it. Try it. :]
author: Eudora Z.

description: This lake is GINORMOUS, when I'm fit or ambitious enough, I have to run it. I guess running this lake is one of my life goals, but for now I'll bike it. It takes me about half an hour to bike the entire lake, not going through the short cut way.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Well, it's out there...but that means more distance to cover, right? I recently ran to/around Lake Merced. It's a good spot, almost reminds me of not-as-beautiful Lake Tahoe...
I find there's something quite comforting about running around an amoeba-shaped body of water (or maybe it's me coming from a desert lifestyle).

Aaaah, I was really enjoying the serenity at Lake Merced until a guy caught up to me and asked for my number (yes, i am still trying to figure this out). Also watch the traffic, as it's 50mph on one side of the lake! Um, ya, so now I'm kinda questioning it.. yep, it just lost a star.
author: Nicole L.

description: My favorite place to run because of the trail (dirt or cement) and you don't have to stop for cars. Perfect place if you just want to get away and have a carefree run outdoors. Run once feel good, run twice feel awesome.
author: Kevin C.

description:
As I am trying to tone up and lose some weight before a weekend in Vegas, I decided I was going to pick up running as my main exercise/fat reducer. And, specifically at Lake Merced because every time I go, I aim to improve my time. Sometimes it happens, sometimes not... but, such is life. 

Running/fast jogging all the way without stopping hasn't happened for me yet. But I hope to get to that point soon. With stopping to walk in between running/fast jogging, I can finish the lake in an hour (most recent time as of yesterday and am so proud since I am not sporty or athletic at all!!). It used to take me an hour 20 or 25. But, I have learned to persevere and keep up my pace. 

The long stretches of pavement are daunting but I don't look ahead, I look at the ground right in front of me so I don't get tired too fast. Also, having my iPod shuffle with me helps me get through running around the lake (don't know how some people get along without some sort of music device..).

Some spots are smelly - the fish spots, the portable, some grassy/bushy areas. But I just hold my breath, and keep on going. And going... and going...
author: Christine C.

description: Great place to walk or jog and have a nice view of the lake. It's mostly flat and about 4 miles around. Pretty heavy traffic with people on the weekends.  If you are walking or jogging with your earbuds in be careful of bike riders, you are supposed to stay to your right.  One time I stopped to take a break from jogging and wasn't aware that there was a guy on a bike right behind me.  He fell into the bushes trying to steer away from hitting me. oooops my bad! So be careful and considerate of those around you. There are benches scattered around to sit and enjoy the view and plenty of free parking all around.
author: Charla M.

description:
for the longest time i couldn't get a straight answer out of people. is the circumference around lake merced 4 miles or 5?? people who want to believe they are in more excellent shape than they really are will tell you 5 miles. but it's 4...or slightly over 4. i took the liberty of driving my car around the lake with my odometer set to zero and i came up with 4.3 miles. of course that's probably a little off, so i'm going to say it's probably about 4.15 miles. i pretty decent run/jog if you want flat roads.

i like that at two locations people have placed "missing keys" on a board for people to reclaim. it's that kind of gesture that makes this world a better place. easily people could ignore keys or throw them away but no, no! not at lake merced. let the key sit there for a year or two. maybe someone will find their key eventually. 

the only negative thing i have to say is that on hot, muggy kinds of days the exhaust from cars driving by is heightened about ten fold and it's pretty gross.
author: Regina C.

description:
I really want to like Lake Merced--and I actually do--but I feel bad, though justified, in giving it only three stars.

I guess I feel like it should be better since it's a natural (?) lake in a major urban area.  I like that it actually comprises three bodies of water (although it used to be one back in the day) and that you can just walk through the weeds to the shore.

But it's just kind of there.  I've walked parts of it a few times, but that's it.  In order for it to warrant four stars, I have to want to come here often, and I don't.
author: John S.

description:
It's a nice park but I wish the route around the park wasn't so flat. Also, you may go for quite a long distance before seeing a garbage can. My friend wanted to throw away her corn on the cob but had to wait a really long distance before we saw one. 

There is a narrow dirt path that many runners use. I suggested that my friend stick out the corn on the cob like a baton in relay running and see if one of the runners will grab it.  It's like when someone is passing out flyers downtown and you grab it even when you don't want it. It's a knee jerk reaction. Think it would work?

There was also this woman doing power walking with two dumbbell weights. I told my friend to slip the dumbbell out of her hand and replace it with the corn on the cob. You're right, that probably also would not work.

But alas, we finally encountered two garbage cans. They were at a parking lot not too far from SF State and I think they were only there so that dog owners could throw away their doggie poop (there were plastic bags near the garbage cans).

Also, be careful that you don't make sudden large movements to the left or the right. A few times, cyclists whizzed by and if we had made a move at the wrong moment, we would be eating dirt. Well, I guess we at least have something to go with the corn on the cob.
author: Wendy L.

description: This place took 2 1/2 hours to walk it.....The place is beautiful....My man brought me here to walk off some calories......It was an easy walk.....Besides the bathroom on the boat house lot, there is one more porta potty on the other side, that's about it, so go prepared......I saw these boards up on both sides of Lake that had hooks on them, when I got closer to take a look, they were for found keys and sunglasses....that was so cool.....There's also a non-profit shooting range for clay discs on the other side............They also have picnic tables which is a good thing nowadays with all these budget cuts......And the place is very clean, so go for it...............
author: Leslie Y.

description:
Ran around the lake for the first time on Saturday...well sorta, I did take the shortcut across the bridge which made it into a 3 mile run.  It was a great cure for a hangover tho.

It's a nice run, especially for us who grew up around the neighborhood.  Just running by all the different areas brought back fond memories, like the boat house and the zoo.

Weren't many people on the path, which was good, but I heard that if you went on a weekday after work, its a diff story.  

All in all a great run, will do it again soon.
author: Eric W.

description:
Excellent trail run (approx 4 miles) tons of runners, walkers, parents with strollers and dogs...ample parking space and a great location to get a good run without crossing major streets or dealing with tons of cars. A decent trail to get your daily cardio fix for the days away from the gym. 

This was also part of the SF marathon course which was a good warm-up for this non-SF native.
author: Ligaya C.

description:
This is a nice place to jog.  It's about 4 &1/2 miles around the entire lake and some parts are pretty nice.  However, there is a section of the trail that seems closer to running on the street then running by a lake.  
There aren't any hills so that is a huge plus and all along the trail there are different exercise stations so you could really get a great workout if you want.  

Something to be aware of is that there are no water fountains so you should make sure you have your own water with you.  If you get in a bind, though, there are fountains at Harding park half way around the trail.
author: Mary Kate M.

description:
Due to negative association, I never gave Lake Merced a chance while I was in nursing school at SFSU. That place made me miserable and I always wanted to run like hell when I was finished with my classes. 

Well, when I was finished with school, I decided to check it out. I was pleasantly surprised and found it to be a great place for a long walk or a run (short run for me!). Parking is never a problem and it's never been too crowded. 

I usually cut through the golf course to escape some of the traffic noise and use the bathrooms. There's a nice-looking restaurant on the golf course with a big deck that might be a nice place for a mid-walk break and snack.
author: Abby W.

description: It hurts to work out, but this place is magical.  You can totally just start conditioning say, 3 months before that vacation or 4 before that marathon, and if you come here enough, the lady of the Lake they call Merced will transform your fat and flabby back to ripe and sexy!  I'll make sure to make a double pass for that second look when I pass you up while jogging!
author: Michael B.

description:
Lake Merced is beautiful and has lots of potential.  Unfortunately, golfers own all of the prime real estate here and the other 95% of the population isn't allowed on most of the surrounding land.

I'll give it 5 stars when its not a monument to golf.  Not holding my breath, though.
author: chadmalik ..

description:
I really like Lake Merced because of the fact that it offers one nice long loop for those training for running events. The weather is usually nice and clear and not too hot. You get a decent breeze from the ocean on the north western side of the Lake, and the south eastern side gives you a long slight downhill to make up for the long slight up hill on the opposite side of the lake. 

On the negative side; the loop is also a big loop for cars with the road being just beside the trail you occasionally have to deal with bus fumes and the like. Also, and I implore all walkers. PLEASE walk on the pavement. The reason why a runner like me is running on the dirt path is that when you are running multiple laps, your legs really begin to hurt and tire. You need every aid you can get, and one is the softer ground of the trail vs. the pavement. When you are walking, you really don't need the trail and you force the runner to go around and onto the pavement which can add to their pain. I am very grateful to those walkers (and runners that are going against the grain) that do make room for runners.

If there were no cars and the trail was wider it would easily get 4 stars.
author: riz n.

description:
Great spot for wildlife viewing. It is a good spot to view an osprey. 

Lake Merced is a major birding area. Various swallows nest their. Red tail and red shoulder hawk breed here. This is a major rookery for blue heroin and double crested heron.
author: Stevs K.

description: This is a great place to push a stroller, and get some fresh air. Plenty of parking, and many of the paths have been recently re-surfaced.
author: Melissa B.

description:
I'm rating this place for the scenerie, the jogging lane, the hiking paths, and the fishing. The scenerie is nice, but was so much nicer 20 years ago. The golf course sucked it's water away. The hike is quite nice. Check out this path near Lowell for a great view of the entire lake.  The fishing really really sucks now. The bait shop is closed, so I don't know where to get your daily permit. The old-timers say you can still catch some whoppers, but I've tried with no success. Now, on to the highlight, jogging.

I would've given this scenic jogging route 5 stars, but they really need lighting at night. It's too dark & dangerous to be there when the sun sets unless you're looking for somewhere to make out. 

Tip: Park in the lot right off of Merced & Brotherhood Way and run clockwise for the maxium jog. Also, watch out for some uneven pavement unless you want to twist an ankle.
author: Axel G.

description:
5 stars for memories...  Fishing with pops.  High school crew practice finding dead bodies.  Parties at the boat house.  Workouts with gfs trying to loose the baby weight.  

It's a good location in the city.  I just wished that it was taken better care of.  It has SO much potential to be one of the center points in the city.  

Beware, if you ride your bike or run around the lake there are tiny bugs in the air.  Keep your mouth closed!!  Lake Merced probably takes about 30% of my lifetime bug diet.  :)
author: Mayah C.

description:
I miss Lake Merced.  I used to come here often when I lived in the area.  It was during a time when I wanted to pursue an interest in running and staying in shape, and the easy (it didn't seem too easy at first!) 4.5 mile loop was a good starting point for my new fitness endeavor.  With a multi-use path, I would also bike on occassion; it made for a variety of recreation options... 

Or, one could just sit on a bench, people watch, and contemplate life while watching seagulls fly over the Lake.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I'm not sure what's right - my polar distance watch or this 4.5 mile rumor.  I clocked the distance at almost 4.7 miles.  

Hmm.

Either way, great run.  First time around, the incline was cake... my 2nd time around it just about gave me a heart attack.

Doing it again this weekend.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Great location.
This is the ultimate place to do some road work (run) and the ocean breeze is just enough to help you cool, down on those rare sunny days in the city.
Its 5miles if you go all the way with it and the inclines give plenty of challenges.
The only negative I have are the road conditions.  at the southern part of the course its been under road construction for almost a year now and you are forced to jog on to oncoming traffic (but dont worry, theres a barrier there to protect you) and the side walk isn't in any good condition in some areas. 
Perfect for BBQ's and to just lounge about thinking of whatever comes to mind.
author: Riko H.

description: Usually, I go for walks in Golden Gate Park.  Today, I thought I'd mix it up a little bit and check out Lake Merced instead.  It always looks so pretty when I pass it on the 18 bus on my way to Trader Joe's.  So my buddy and I decided to get our walk on.  I was expecting a nice path around the perimeter of the Lake, maybe some ducks, nothing too special.  What I got was walking on a multi-use path next to a busy street with cars rushing by and also a lot of used toilet paper and litter on the nature trails.  Yech!  We did walk all the way around the lake, but how stressful to have to be next to heavy traffic 80% of the time.  Horrendous!  If you're heading out this way and looking for some nice nature, go to Fort Funston instead.
author: Harvey R.

description:
I like trails or walks to get away from the hustle and bustle of people and cars. Well, if you are looking for solitude, this isn't the path to take. It's an easy 4-5 mile walk, but you have to deal with vehicles constantly driving by. It's a great mid point to meet friends who live on the other side of town from you. I am over in the richmond district & I have a friend I normally meet from the Bernal Heights Area, so it's a happy medium. 

I really don't like pigeons, so there is an area where you can get bombed by them, if you are not careful.
author: M M.

description:
in its prime, lake merced was one of the nation top urban fisheries. in the late 80s and 90s, due to several reasons such as over pumping of the underground water and of the over development of the areas surrounding the lake, lake merced went to shit. 

i fondly remember going out on the boats rented at the boat house (thats no longer there) purchasing some salmon eggs and hooks at the baitshop (thats no longer there) and heading out on the northside with pops. its one of those rare picturesque moments from my childhood. 

because of organizations like caltrout and friends of lake merced who basically pretty much forced the hand of the dfg to restock the lake to rebalance the ecosystem and provide "sport" for us urban dwellers, forced the developers of lake merced golf course to develop with the lake in mind and stopped the dpw from pumping the underground water, lake merced is coming back. 

i cant imagine not having this oasis here. it is a refuge for me and something i hold very dear to me. 

i also run the lake. five minutes away from my urban hell hole home, 15 minutes from my blue collar warehouse, theres is this gem on the southside of the city were i can forget the troubles of the day and hopefully be able to make it back to my car at the circle. 

how wonderful will it be if we could bring back lake merced to its former glory and i could take my future fucked up kids (yes fucked up, they will be mine after all) and enjoy a nice simple afternoon of bbq, fishing and just being a family together. 

fyi if you have kids between the ages of  5-16, you just might want to participate in trout day at lake merced.

http://www.caltrout.org/article.asp?id=41

they overstock the lake and net the trout into a small area for kids to come with their families and have a great FREE day with each other.
author: Euge L.

description: This lake is truly a wonderful place to relax or take a long walk. I think you can also fish in some parts of the lake but then you have to put them back.
author: Joshua L.

description: been the spot for sf outdoor park outings....bbqs or watching dragon boat races...si..only care to watch...never participate....fear of public waters.....moving on....relatively a scenic park...waters of lake merced....grills and picnic tables...for gatherings, food and fun.....from memorable "jam out with your clam out" to the recent "the proustian picnic pot luck porno shoot ".....always good times with good food at lake merced.....grassy greens for frolic fun.....although failed miserably at bean bag tossing....can't get it in the hole~!!@@!!!....urgh....only negatives being....unpredictable weather conditions....from sunny to cloudy...mild to windy....always best to bring layers......parking also limited during sunny days.....
author: Hen A.

description: I caught my first fish here!  Many years later I partied, hard, at the Boathouse.  I love this place.
author: Janet W.

description: I felt like THE shit the first time I conquered the 4.5 mile run around the lake! its a really good run, and its nice to enjoy the great outdoors while getting a workout vs. running on a treadmill at the gym all the time. the fresh air feels wonderful, except when its freaking freezing and then your nose starts running.. . faster than you. hah ha.. not funny, okay anyways. the weather could fluctuate a lot with the daly city fog just nearby, so wear layers if you go out!
author: Jennie L.

description: All parks should be given five stars unless they have crack heads and ugly prostitutes hanging out in them. This is a spectacular place to run, about 5 miles around the loop. A large lake with boats and ducks swimming around and crapping everywhere. Lot's of people walking and running. It's right near the ocean, near Fort Funston so you get the ocean breeze. Plenty of parking on the north west side off of sunset blvd.
author: Phil M.

description:
observations and things i have learned about myself while walking around lake merced...

-i have a really hard time walking to music.  i find myself walking in weird steps that make me look dorky... all because a slow beck song is on.  i just have to move my legs to the beat.

-shuffle mode is not conducive to walking fast.  sure...if it's welcome to the jungle i can walk like those dudes in the olympics.  but then it turns into hurt by johnny cash and i slow to a crawl and start bawling.  it just doesn't work for me.

-i have a fear of groups of boats.  some people get nervous when they see a group of unruly teens or a group of dogs.  i get nervous when i see a group of boats.  i love lake merced because the most boats you'll see together is like 5... and they're row team boats... which don't bother me for some reason.

-i get wicked walking anxiety when someone is behind me.  i can't think about anything other than that person.  i pretend to look out at the lake, but really i just want to get a glimpse of the creeper walking two feet behind me.  i hate that.

-i get wicked walking anxiety when walking behind someone.  i don't want to be a creeper so i try to pass the person.  inevitably they will speed up because, really, it is a race.  so that forces me to walk as hard as i can (cause i don't run, folks) and pass on the right.  this has proved to be a very dangerous move.

-groups of birds make me nervous and sick.  the section by the cheaters bridge with all the birds is something i lay awake at night thinking about.  it's just all so unsanitary and yucky.   remember that seinfield episode with george and the bird rule that they are supposed to move?  well they don't.  

-regarding the cheaters bridge...if given the opportunity to cheat...i have discovered that 9 times out of 10 i will cheat.  at least i'm honest.
author: Katie H.

description:
i have been here for dragonboat practices, races and to wander aimlessly.

the cold was brutal on race days when i was drenched in the fairly malodorous water but on other occasions, when i was solo and willing to let the melancholy set in for a bit, i looked forward to the gray.  

i like that i can enjoy this place in big groups or by myself.  if only it weren't so stinky sometimes.
author: Seong P.

description:
Well, I try to run/walk this lake about 3 days a week, and, though it has always been there for me - good times and bad, and has provided me with cheap, easy and usually good exercise,  I do have a couple of gripes. 
1. Traffic - it is right there which gets a little old.
2. Not enough cushy stuff to run on.
3. It gets kind of boring after a while going around in circles. To mix it up sometimes I go crazy and go the other way around the lake. Sometimes I go really wacky and cross the street to Fort Funston and go up and down the stairs.
author: Avril S.

description: I Love this place. Perfect for skipping stones and bike riding when Spring hits. This place reminds me of good times during my childhood.
author: Jordan A.

description:
i've run around this lake at least a thousand times; a truly wonderful place to run.

i miss the boathouse.
author: vincent m.

description: Let's just say that I wouldnt have entered marathons, danced with strong legs till the break of dawn and forgotten about problems without my runs around Lake Merced...I love this lake because it pushes you to run the whole time around the lake. Yes, it can get crowded morning and early afternoons during weekends and cars may pass you by all the time but it is convenient, plenty of parking and the views are refreshing...It is also near westlake shopping center for any grocery shopping before you head back home. I love Lake Merced...so many memories tied to this place
author: Charmian D.

description:
i am seriously a lazy ass that hates exercise! 
but when i think about the fresh air at lake merced, it actually motivates me.

This is a great place for joggers, runners, walkers and bikers!
author: Eva L.

description:
Lake Merced is probably my favorite place in SF to run.  The main reason is because the route is a complete loop around the lake, and once you get past a certain point, there's no turning back regardless of how lazy you feel, unless you want to swim.  It forces me to do the entire loop (4.5 miles) and the breeze there is usually very refreshing.  I've been fooled enough times to know that it may be a bit chilly when I start the run, but never, ever wear a long sleeve t-shirt because by the time I'm done, I've taken it off and it becomes a major pain in the azz to carry around while running.

Parking is also generally very good, unless there's some type of dragon boating event, which is maybe a few times a year.  There's also usually a medium-ish amount of people around, either running or picnicking, etc so that if you collapse after your run, there will be at least a few people who could call 911 on your behalf.  Seriously, the last thing I want is to be found a few days after I collapse from a heart attack, half eaten by insects.  I want an open casket funeral!
author: Stan L.

description: 6:30am is freakin' cold, but this place is pretty good for a morning run.  Mostly flat with a few very slight inclines.  I still don't know the exact distance, as it varies from website to website.  4.25, 4.5, 4.75 or 5 miles?  Which one is it?  Someone please tell me so I can finally know my average mile times!!  Arrrrgh!  LOL!  One thing for sure, you say "Hi" to someone on this trail and 99% of the people say it right back to you.  Much appreciated, whether you are a walker, jogger, runner or bike rider.  Park near the end of Brotherhood Way so you can get that downhill at the end of your run.  Great way to finish the course.  Happy running!
author: Mario P.

description:
love lake merced.  dont like the fishermen there.  

My co worker wambu and i ran there.
author: Roger A.

description: I really like Lake Merced.  Although it's little close to the road where the car runs.  Then again, what more can you ask for in a city.   I do enjoy running around the lake.  Well, more like walking, I can't run far and long.   It's not too long and not too steep.
author: Xiu L.

description: I think this is the perfect Sunday morning walk. Pretty scenery, friendly Sunday am strollers and the perfect length. Go early...before the runners and bicyclists take over with their shouts of "Coming through!" and "There's a bike lane!".  Yeesh.
author: Melinda B.

description: I remember coming here once with my siblings and my dad on a warm afternoon.  We rented a row boat and took it out.  It was a calm, peaceful.  And as the sun began to dip behind the eucalyptus, we headed back.  Fast forward fifteen years and the boats are gone along with my childhood.  I've got three and a half miles ahead of me and a pair of Asics that rhythmically beat the pavement.  Parking?  No worries.  Weather?  Good all year 'round, so long as it's not raining.  Despite the exhaust coming off the surrounding 35mph zones, Lake Merced is definitely one of the things that makes living in San Francisco awesome.
author: Tony L.

description: I have fond memories of Lake Merced from my high school days. No, I didn't jog around the lake nor was I part of the crew team. You haven't truly experienced Lake Merced until you've stumbled around there at night. Mist rising off the surface of the lake as the fog rolls in-- It's both glorious and eerie. The car lights streaming by suddenly look amazing! And then you somehow end up at the Oakwood apartment bathrooms thinking there are cockroaches all over the floor and sit on the counter all night talking to your best friend... oh, I guess that has nothing to do with the lake. Never mind. Um, it's a pretty lake. You should go.
author: Michie L.

description: A great place to unwind and exercise. Really refreshing in the morning.
author: Rachel F.

description: Lake Merced is wonderful.  Biked there twice already. It's a good distance and is fairly flat.  There's many sights along the path and you also pass a skeet shooting range which  i never knew existed.  There's also a bunch of resting spots, workout areas and look out points along the path for those who like to stop and take a break for lunch or a snack.  People who walk and ride on the path are friendly and the road isn't ridden with pothole or other hazards.  It's close enough to sunset also that I can just get there in a few minutes!
author: LittleBird 8.

description: I am a total fan.  The lake is clean and really pretty.  I am not a big fan of the road that goes along the lake, but I am not really complaining.
author: Rikki G.

description:
Pros: 
You can run/jog/walk/bike all on the same path. 
There are places to rest along the way
There are public bathrooms
Last I recall, there are 5 bus stops along the lake
There's a bridge to "cheat" from having to go the full distance
There's a decent sized parking lot
First come first serve on picnic tables, no reservations
Alcohol is allowed

Cons:
It's really not the most eye appealing place to jog out doors in SF (think Ocean Beach and Crissy Fields)
Not the best lit place to jog in the evenings/night
I've found certain parts of the route to smell bad
Parking can get crazy when there are events going on (think boat races)
First come first serve on picnic tables, no reservations
author: Ro F.

description: I was told just the other day when I was taking a nice pleasant stroll around the lake to "GET THE F@!#% out of the way" by this bicyclist. Um ok.  It is a good place to get some cardio but I cannot help but feel there are lots of crazy mofos hanging around there.  Whenever I go for a run here, its like I am just waiting for somebody to jump out of the bushes and do something horrible to me.  Does anyone else feel that way???  Next time I think I should just go running strapped with my AK-47.
author: Micaela M.

description: Lake Merced brings back childhood memories.. This is the place where my dad taught me how to ride my bike.. On the weekends he would take my brother and i for an impromtu picnic during the summer... When I was in high school our track team would train here... Nothing like running at full speed with the ocean breeze on your face.. Fast forward twelve years and I have rediscovered my love for running around the loop... I like that it's a flat course and good for my aging knees... Lake Merced will always have a place in my heart...
author: Trish P.

description: Great easy loop.  Inside the city, but far enough removed.  Moderate trail traffic. I enjoy seeing all the people; but there aren't TOO many people. One star off for protruding roots in the asphalt, although, I'm sure if our parks received more funding this wouldn't be an issue. I don't go here all the time, but I enjoy going here when I need a change of scenery.
author: Carey L.

description: Lake Merced has a special place in my heart.  It was the last place that I drove Curly to and gave him a walk.  The sky was overcast and dark gray.  He still had some pep in him, and thankfully was able to walk a bit around and enjoy himself.
author: jen a.

description: I love Lake Merced . It's very beautiful and lovely with the lakes , trees , and grass . It wonderfully reflects nature =] . It's a nice break from the tall buildings in our city . It just seems kind of dangerous driving through here ..
author: Eileen L.

description: Dude, that can't be a picture of Lake Merced! Seriously, murky and sad is the best way to describe this lake. So, you ask why I gave it 3 stars, eh? I run around that darn thing, and it's like butta! And, though icky, I enjoy looking out on the water, then turning my head and looking out at the traffic. Really, what more could you ask for.......ok, that's sad.
author: Jewel N.

description: Great place to run, just make sure you stay clear of all the other runners, walkers, dog-walkers and joggers! The place can get crowded when it's a nice day or a weekend so parking may be slightly hard.
author: Janel Y.

description: This lake is pretty damn big. Lots of people decide to have bbqs here, and I think thats is very easy to get lost here as well. Maybe I've seen too much ground and not enough lake for the times I've been here. I need to see more. But also somewhere I wouldn't prefer being at night.
author: Elaine H.

description: Good location for a long stretch of area to run or walk - without having to cross any streets. The scenery cuts between to worlds - cars and traffic on one side, the lake with shrubbery on the other. This area could use more lighting for evening recreation.
author: Judy L.

description: The lake is really nice to go for a jog but you have to pass SFSU where all the cars drive by to get onto Hwy 280, so breathing all that exhaust isn't good for you.  Parts of the road offer different views - golf course, the shooting range (gets loud when the rifle men are out there being macho), apt buildiings/housing.
